newsitem.title: USA: Zilog promotes Internet TV box under $200.
newsitem.headline: Zilog promotes Internet TV box under $200.

text.p: Semiconductor maker Zilog Inc. and privately-held consumer Internet software developer PlanetWeb said they have developed an integrated design for building television set-top boxes for Internet access that can retail for less than $200.

The announcement, to be formally released on Monday, follows a number of similar designs by Internet startups such as ICTV, NetChannel, Inc. and WebTV Network, the last of which Microsoft Corp. agreed last month to acquire for $425 million, mostly in Microsoft stock.
Unlike the other offerings, the Zilog-PlanetWeb offering is not currently available and it will rely on manufacturing partners to build and market the devices.
But the devices themselves are well below the current level of Internet devices now on the market for up to $400 each.

Zilog, a supplier to the television industry, said in a statement the device specification includes a built-in modem and allows users to access the Internet using virtually any Internet service provider.

This is a contrast to WebTV, for example, which as the pioneer of the Internet television space requires customers to also use its WebTV Network service in order to be able to use its set-top devices.

Zilog said its Internet appliance reference design, licensed from MSU Corp. of Milton Keynes, England, includes four megabytes of memory for storage of downloaded Web pages and two megabytes of downloaded read- only flash program storage memory.
The design also allows for users to print Web pages.
Zilog said it is contracting with a third-party manufacturer to provide sample units to potential makers of the device, with sampling units expected to be available in the third quarter of this year.
